subsc: Other social services,Health,Central government administration,General agriculture, fishing and forestry sector

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, though institutional
            development impacts were only modest. Lessons for nutrition
            projects suggest that it is possible to reduce severe
            malnutrition in a relatively short period of time, provided
            mothers are better trained by specialized workers, and
            educated with intensive counseling on food supplements.
            Moreover, under-nourishment of women during pregnancy can
            also be reduced through adequate education, and food
            supplements. Lessons for community-based programs include
            participation and involvement, to induce behavioral changes,
            through widespread community mobilization, particularly
            women's involvement in communication activities, in the
            preparation of supplementary foods, and in growth monitoring
            of their children. General lessons suggest the inclusion of
            operational research, along with integrated, complementary
            approaches, which should be incorporated early on in the
            project design, to include efforts that increase household
            food security, and nutritional services, coordinated by
            nongovernmental organizations.
